repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
- It's not easy for users to update/delete a plugin because they have to type full name of the plugin.

Solution:
- Add `:packupdate` and `:packdelete` commands, which support completing name of packages managed by `vim.pack`.

ping @echasnovski @justinmk 

Close #34764 

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body: I'd expect both `update` and `delete` commands to accept several plugins to act upon. The same as `vim.pack.update()` and `vim.pack.del()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -279,10 +274,28 @@ Unfreeze plugin to start receiving updates:
   want it to be updated.
 • |:restart|.
 
-Remove plugins from disk:
-• Use |vim.pack.del()| with a list of plugin names to remove. Make sure their
-  specs are not included in |vim.pack.add()| call in 'init.lua' or they will
-  be reinstalled.
+
+COMMANDS ~
+
+:packupdate[!] {plugin}                                          *:packupdate*

comment_data.body:
In that case, if a package contains space, users would need to escape it, right? (because `vim.pack.add()` allows users to set name)

Btw, I have [another branch](https://github.com/brianhuster/neovim/tree/pack-cmd-multiargs) that implements multi-args support for these 2 commands

@@ -279,10 +274,28 @@ Unfreeze plugin to start receiving updates:
   want it to be updated.
 • |:restart|.
 
-Remove plugins from disk:
-• Use |vim.pack.del()| with a list of plugin names to remove. Make sure their
-  specs are not included in |vim.pack.add()| call in 'init.lua' or they will
-  be reinstalled.
+
+COMMANDS ~

comment_data.body: Sure, as in any other command.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -279,10 +274,28 @@ Unfreeze plugin to start receiving updates:
   want it to be updated.
 • |:restart|.
 
-Remove plugins from disk:
-• Use |vim.pack.del()| with a list of plugin names to remove. Make sure their

+

comment_regular_data.body:
I personally think that choosing names `:packupdate` and `:packdelete` leads to many complications in the presence of `:packadd`. The fact that `:packupdate` /  `:packdelete` directly use `vim.pack.update()` / `vim.pack.del()` *but* `:packadd` doesn't use `vim.pack.add()` (in fact it is the opposite) is and will be pretty confusing.

My preference would be for a regular user commands (`:PackAdd`, `:PackUpdate`, `:PackDelete`) because they are pretty clearly different from `:packadd`. Maybe having a single `:pack` (lowercase or uppercase) is doable, but it loses the discoverability/documentability of separate commands.

> The fact that :packupdate / :packdelete directly use vim.pack.update() / vim.pack.del() but :packadd doesn't use vim.pack.add() (in fact it is the opposite) is and will be pretty confusing.

Actually I think what is confusing is that `:packadd` and `:packloadall` manage all packpaths, while `:packupdate` and `:packdel` only manage one of them. I agree that they should change the names, but I still prefer if they are all lower-case because:
- Separation between built-in and 3rd-party plugins (just like why all stdlibs must be in `vim` module), all built-in namespaces must be prefixed with `nvim.`
- Easier to discover, because they are in `index.txt`

Maybe could use `:pkg` prefix instead (because the `packspec` file is named `pkg.json`)? But then `vim.pack` probably should be renamed to `vim.pkg` as well?

I tried to make it clear in #34764 that we should wait on this. Don't want to spend time on it now. See where the pain points are first. I've been doing: 

    nvim -c 'lua vim.pack.update()'

Haven't had a problem with that.

> I'd expect both `update` and `delete` commands to accept several plugins to act upon. The same as `vim.pack.update()` and `vim.pack.del()`.

That's exactly the kind of thing that doesn't make sense. If an Ex command starts to accept multiple args, that's leaning towards a "programmatic" use-case. But we already have `vim.pack.update()`, so there is no reason to also provide the same features in a `:packupdate` Ex command.

If there are interactive use-cases that really matter, we can address those. But we need to see what those are. Just duplicating the programmatic interface in Ex commands is not valuable.

I'm not convinced that updating a specific plugin with `:packupdate` is useful. If you don't want to update other plugins, then you should pin them...

> I'm not convinced that updating a specific plugin with :packupdate is useful. If you don't want to update other plugins, then you should pin them...

Sometimes I update a plugin _just because_ it is buggy at that moment. In that case, updating all plugins don't make sense, because I would have to review changes for a lot more plugins.

It's _not_ the same as "I _never_ want to update other plugins", it's just I don't want to do that _at that moment_.  In this case, going to config to pin other plugins, and then `:restart` Nvim seems overkill for me.

> It's _not_ the same as "I _never_ want to update other plugins", it's just I don't want to do that _at that moment_. In this case, going to config to pin other plugins, and then `:restart` Nvim seems overkill for me.

To be fair, this can be done with `:lua vim.pack.update({ 'bad-plugin' })`. The only convenience of dedicated commands is less typing plus completion.

Plus if/when #34919 is merged, this will also be possible with `:lua vim.pack.update()` + examine changelog + `gra` + choose update a single plugin.

> Plus if/when #34919 is merged, this will also be possible with :lua vim.pack.update() + examine changelog + gra + choose update a single plugin.

Looks like #34919 also allows users to choose a plugin to delete, which is also what I want. If it can do that even without internet, then this PR can be closed

> If it can do that even without internet, then this PR can be closed

Currently it does require internet connection, yes. It will be possible to add public `opts.offline` to `vim.pack.update()` for confirmation buffer to act as sort of dashboard, but that needs discussion.

> Plus if/when #34919 is merged, this will also be possible with :lua vim.pack.update() + examine changelog + gra + choose update a single plugin.

But it still requires users to download all updates first

So I think it would be nice if `nvim-pack`buffer is not limited to `vim.pack.update()` but it can be used as a default dashboard for managing plugins. So users can use `gra + update` to download an update (before confirming/rejecting the update)

> So I think it would be nice if `nvim-pack`buffer is not limited to `vim.pack.update()` but it can be used as a default dashboard for managing plugins. So users can use `gra + update` to download an update (before confirming/rejecting the update)

That's a bit too much. To not download updates for all plugins - `vim.pack.update({ 'plugin1', 'plugin2' })`. After that examine changelog and confirm update for all/some/none. Allowing to selectively download updates after showing all available plugins feels like an unnecessary complication.

The "dashboard like" experience can be achieved with possible `opts.offline = true` for the purpose of examining:
- Which plugins are installed at what path and state.
- Which semver tags are available to update to.
- Apply pending updates (either after changing `version` or if downloaded previously updates were skipped).
- Delete the ones which are not needed.

I.e. the same experience as with `opts.offline = false`, but skipping downloading updates thus not requiring Internet connection.
Instead of `:packupdate` and `:packdelete`, can we instead have `:pack update` and `:pack delete`?

> Instead of :packupdate and :packdelete, can we instead have :pack update and :pack delete?

~~Of course~~, but as Echasnovski said before, implementing bang like `:pack! update` doesn't look very natural.

Anyway, since there are a lot of things to consider about these commands, I will step down on this at least until `vim.pack` is released
@justinmk  Excuse me, I don't know what you need me to response to?

title: feat(ex): add `:packupdate` and `:packdelete` commands [skip ci]
